projects.name: MyOwnTrainer
projects.description: Personal Fitness App that connects with a MYO Armband. Third Place at Ryerson Sportshack

subpages.value: MyOwnTrainer is an app that monitors the number of reps that the user does by collecting and analyzing data from the Myo Armband. Created by a team of 4, winning Third Place at SportsHack. Bruce Croxon judged the event and gave our team feedback on the App.

projects.name: Blizzard XIV
projects.description: Annual FRC Robot created by a highschool robotics team that I mentor.

subpages.value: These are some robots that I have created with my highschool robotics team, to compete in the annual First Robotics Competition. The robot was designed, machined and built by a team of 30 students that I lead when I was in 12th grade. I am currently a mentor for Team 188 focusing on the enrichment and education of the students on the team.

projects.name: OneMark
projects.description: Unique App created to allow TDSB students to access all of their marks in one intuitive UI. Second Place at MARS EdAppHack

subpages.value: OneMark is an app that grabs students' marks from their online classrooms and displays them in a simple yet informative user interface. Created by a team of 6, winning Second Place at EdAppHack .

projects.name: Vex
projects.description: Annual VEX Robot created using VEX Robotics parts and geared towards the Vex Robotics Competition. Regional Semifinalists: (2012, 2013, 2014).

subpages.value: This robot was designed to compete in the 2014 Vex Robotics Competition. I designed and built this robot with a team of 4 other students, while I was in 12th grade.

projects.name: QuadCopter
projects.description: I designed and built a Quadcopter from scratch using Arduino and programming an Android App to control it.

subpages.value: For my grade 12 Tech Design Project, I chose to design and build my own Quadcopter. I sourced some parts online and am on target to complete the project by May. Check out my latest update which showcases the Android App communicating with the Arduino to control a servo.

projects.name: PhysicsWorld
projects.description: Physics Simulation App created for a Grade 11 Computer Science Assignment. (My first Android App)

subpages.value: Physics World is an app that allows users to simulate physics problems in a 2D-Physics Engine that I programmed myself. The entire app was created by a team of 4 Grade 11 students for Computer Science Project.

projects.name: BinLoco
projects.description: In partnership with the City of Toronto, we used Open Data to create an app that navigates the user to the closest garbage or recycling bin.

subpages.value: Working with Open Data provided by the City of Toronto the team and I programmed an app that finds the closest garbage or recycling bin to the user. The app was decided as the best app and presentation by the Judges.

projects.name: ImAgenda
projects.description: This app lets you take the picture of a printed schedule and converts it into events you can save in your phone.

subpages.value: I created this app as a group project for a course in software engineering. I set up the infrastructure of the Android app, wrote all of the OpenCv code (grid detection+ ocr) and uses threads to run the processing in the background while giving visual updates to the UI.

projects.name: Nutty Ninjas
projects.description: For my 11th grade final project, I created a game that featured an advanced AI.

subpages.value: A game about battling ninjas that I made for my grade 11 final project. The built-in AI uses a machine learning algorithm capable of learning and executing complex time-sensitive strategies in less than 10 matches against a smart opponent.

value: Let's break down how the AI learns:
There are 40 text files each representing a time slot (at the moment the time slots are 6 seconds each) in the game. These files start out empty.
Each Fighter keeps a log of it's activities and stores them into an array at the end of every timeframe. Even the human controlled fighters will keep a record of the action being executed.

When a fighter dies, or it wins the game. It's log is stored into the text files in the following way: The fighter's actions during the first timeframe as well as whether or not the fighter won is stored in 'aiMemory1.txt', it's actions and success for the next timeframe is stored in 'aiMemory2.txt' and so on for the next 38 timeframes.
The next time the game is played the AI will load in the success rate for each action into variables in the game class.

Consider this example: An AI who one the game, started off by buying a gold buillding in the first timeframe. If only one game has been played, the success rate of buying a gold building in the first timeframe is 100%.
The Fighter AIs mutliply their decisions with the success rates. Thus, the AI is more likely to choose to execute the more successful action.
This way the AI is capable of executing long-term strategies instead of doing the same -very predictable- action the entire game.
